Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Erosion and Weathering Control of Soil Carbon: Tectonics and Plows
Award.AbstractNarration: Soils are chemical reactors. In this vast and diverse crucible that covers the earth surface, minerals undergo a series of physical and chemical reactions with organic matter. These reactions, by controlling the longevity of organic carbon in soils, contribute to the global carbon cycle and act as a control on atmospheric CO2 levels. Little is known, however, about how such reactions are influenced by the supply of minerals into these soil reactors. This study will test a hypothesis that tectonic action, by physically and chemically exposing rock-originated minerals to the Earth's biologically active surface, regulates carbon-mineral interactions. Conversely, in tectonically quiet places, human land-use plays a dominant role as plows replace tectonics, physically mixing minerals and organic matter and facilitating their interactions. This study ultimately attempts to build and empirically test a universal model of carbon-mineral interactions over a gradient from tectonically active rugged terrains (Coastal California and Sierra Nevada California) to tectonically quiet agricultural plains (Midwestern Corn Belt and Atlantic Coastal Plains). Such a global survey of soils will be integrated into an experiential learning module on soil sustainability in an "Environmental Problem Solving" course that is required for all undergraduate students majoring in Environmental Science, Policy, and Management at the University of Minnesota. Students will be guided to build their knowledge base on soil sustainability by collaboratively developing educational materials and using the materials to inform and engage the general public on issues of long-term soil sustainability. The researcher also plans to revise his graduate course on soil formation in order to dramatically boost graduate students? real world experience in conducting science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soil is an important player in the global climate change not only because it stores substantial amount of organic carbon but also because soil carbon is vulnerable to many environmental changes including land uses. Researchers have been aware that soil carbon is not homogeneous but consists of variety of pools that have different reactions to those changes. Among these carbon pools, soil organic carbon that is associated with minerals is considered most stable. Researchers thus seek to understand the genesis and fates of mineral-associated organic carbon pool in soils.

This broad question inevitably calls for integrating the chemistry and physics of both organic matter and minerals on the earth surface. This is exactly what this project was about. We tapped into geochemistry research tools to understand the nature of organic matter and minerals that participate in forming mineral-associated carbon. On the other hand, we investigated the carbon-mineral interactions in soils that are constantly being moved by tectonically-derived erosion, agricultural soil tillage, and by invasive earthworms. Scientific fields of geomorphology, agronomy, and ecology provided us with the tools to quantify those physical perturbations in soils. 

With the interdisciplinary research approaches, we studied mechanisms and rates (1) that slow to rapid soil erosion alters the formation of mineral associated carbon in Northern Sierra Nevada, California and New South Wales in Australia,  (2) that agricultural conversion of grasslands and forests have affected molecular structure of mineral-associated carbon and mineral surface characteristics in the prairie ecosystems in Minnesota and in the coastal plains in Delaware, and (3) that invasive exotic earthworms mix organic litter layer with mineral soil horizons and consequently contribute to the formation of mineral-associated carbon in the formerly glaciated forests in Northern Sweden and Finland.

We found that deep chemical weathering beneath soils is often critically important: soil minerals that have been inherited from deep subsurface weathering play critical role in the formation of mineral-associated carbon in the surface soils. Humans have also made substantial changes in the ways that minerals and organic matter interact, we found. Both farming and human-mediated introduction of geoengieering earthworms, while facilitating physical contacts between organic matter and minerals, also simultaneously reduce available organic matter because of the harvest of crops and accelerated decomposition of organic matter. Thus the net effects of the human-induced changes on mineral-associated carbon become dependent on the balancing acts of the two competing processes. Our results thus show that the mechanisms that soil erosion, farming, earthworm invasion affect mineral-associated carbon are substantially more complicated than previously thought. Understanding the formation of mineral-associated carbon requires multi-disciplinary investigation that covers both earth and ecological science.

The project also involved developing a teaching module on soil erosion for a large undergraduate environmental science course.  The teaching module, once completed, was further expanded to become an independent course on the soils and land uses in different world cultures. By revealing scientific bases underlying diverse ways of modifying and using soils for agricultural production in many world cultures in the past and present, the course seeks to highlight the importance of understanding the carbon cycle and geomorphic processes in pursuing sustainable agriculture and land managements.
